name: Physical Layer
description: Transmits raw bit stream over the physical medium. Deals with the physical characteristics of the transmission medium, such as voltage levels, timing of voltage changes, physical data rates, maximum transmission distances, and physical connectors.

name: Data Link Layer
description: Defines how data is formatted for transmission and how access to the physical media is controlled. It provides reliable transit of data across a physical link by using mechanisms like physical addressing (MAC addresses), network topology, error notification, sequencing of frames, and flow control.

name: Network Layer
description: Determines how data is routed from source to destination across multiple networks (internetworking). It handles logical addressing (IP addresses), routing, and path determination.

name: Transport Layer
description: Provides reliable message delivery or connectionless message delivery between end systems. It segments data from the sending host's system and reassembles the data into a data stream on the receiving host's system. Services include connection-oriented communication, reliability, flow control, and multiplexing.

name: Session Layer
description: Manages sessions (connections) between applications. It establishes, manages, and terminates connections between local and remote applications. It also handles session checkpointing, and recovery.

name: Presentation Layer
description: Translates data between application and network formats. It is responsible for data encryption, decryption, compression, and character set conversion, ensuring that data sent from the application layer of one system can be read by the application layer of another system.

name: Application Layer
description: Provides network services directly to user applications. This layer is closest to the end user. It includes protocols that applications use to exchange data, such as HTTP for web browsing, FTP for file transfer, and SMTP for email.
